Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the parent needs to handle the situation
Situation2: They notice dust and mess building up and carry out more regular cleaning tasks.
Story: I was halfway through scrubbing the kitchen floor, sweat beading on my forehead, when my phone buzzed. It was the store manager—my heart dropped as he explained my son had been caught slipping a candy bar into his pocket. I rushed to the store, my mind racing with what I should say, how I should teach him right from wrong. As a parent, I knew I had to address this, to guide him, to show him stealing was wrong and help him understand the consequences. But as I stood there, my hands still smelling of bleach, I remembered the mess waiting for me at home—the dust gathering on the shelves, the laundry piling up, the expectation that I keep everything spotless. My boss had already warned me about missing spots. I felt torn, pulled between the urgent need to discipline and comfort my child, and the relentless demand to keep the house immaculate. My chest tightened as I looked at my son’s guilty face, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left undone.
